Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Continued study of ULF waves at cusp latitudes on Svalbard to probe Earth's space environment
Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal requests support for the continued operation of, and analysis of data from, a closely-spaced array of four search coil magnetometers (induction antennas) the installation of which began in September 2006 on Svalbard, Norway, for studies of ULF waves and associated phenomena in Earth?s space environment. In addition to induction coil magnetometers, instruments on Svalbard include numerous auroral imagers and photometers, multiple radars including EISCAT, SPEAR, and SuperDARN, and the northernmost stations in the IMAGE array of fluxgate magnetometers. Such a complete suite of instruments enables the association of various features in the observations with specific magnetospheric regions, such as the plasma sheet, low latitude boundary layer, cusp proper, or plasma mantle, with more confidence and reliability than in earlier studies at other locations. The role of induction coil magnetometers is to detect magnetic fluctuations in the frequency range 0.02 - 5 Hz. This project is part of an international effort by the space science community to better understand the dynamics of Earth?s magnetosphere and of its interaction with the solar wind and IMF.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involves a collaboration between the University of New Hampshire and Augsburg College in Minneapolis, MN. The focus of this work involves measurement and analysis of electromagnetic waves that penetrate the ionosphere, having originated in the magnetosphere. The measurements are made using induction coil magnetometers, built at the University of New Hampshire and installed in Svalbard. There are four sites with this equipment, including Ny Alesund, Longyearbyen, Hornsund and Isfjord Radio. The equipment is maintained with support from Norwegian and Polish colleagues.

 

We have used these data to study various  aspects of certain types of waves including Electromagnetic Ion Cyclotron (EMIC) waves and another type called Pi1B pulsations. Our work with EMIC waves has focused primarily on a specific event that occurred in 2010. At that time, a High Speed Stream in the solar wind impacted Earth's magnetosphere, delivering a pressure pulse that, it appears, generated EMIC waves over the course of several days. The first step in our analysis has been to study this persistence since such a thing has never been reported before.

 

The second part of this problem involved studies of Earth's radiation belts, since EMIC waves are thought to interact with the energetic electrons and protons in the radiation belts. We have found conclusive evidence (in satellite data) that electrons did, in fact, precipitate into the upper atmosphere  during this event, as predicted by theory. Previously, a few similar observations have been made in the past, though our study is the first that clearly associates the effect with a High Speed Stream and over the course of several days, which is important for predicting Space Weather.

 

Our work on Pi1B pulsations has involved aspects of their propagation within the ionosphere. Combining our observations with radar observations of the ionosphere, supported by numerical modeling, we have confirmed an hypothesis that these waves can intensify with the so-called Ionospheric Alfven Resonator.

 

In terms of broader impacts, we would highlight the educational aspects of this study. Specifically, the results described above were attained with significant involvement of two students, an undergraduate and a graduate student. In fact, the work on Pi1B pulsations has been submitted for publication by the undergraduate who carried out the work wrote the paper himself.
